subject: Re: java versus junit tasks with ant
msgSnippet: thanks again. i didnt understand why the java task wouldnt have the capability end the build if a test failure occured. then i figured out that it did, and
messageBody:
thanks again. i didnt understand why the java task wouldnt have the
capability end the build if a test failure occured. then i figured
out that it did, and added it into my code. i will definitely use the
junit task in the future.

nathan


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
wrote:
> nathan wrote:
>
> > hello,
> >
> > i have a java-task in an ant builfile that runs(junit)
successfully
> > thanks to this yahoo group, but I am
> > wondering if i am using the wrong task. here is the ant code:
> >
> > <target name="run-tests" description="Test with Junit"
> > depends="compile-tests">
> > <echo message="Running run-tests"/>
> > <java
> > classname="junit.textui.TestRunner"
> > taskname="junit"
> > fork="true">
> > <arg value="${test.classpath}.TestMain"/>
> > <classpath>
> > <pathelement location="${dir.lib}/junit3.8.1.jar"/>
> > <pathelement location="${dir.lib}/log4j-1.2.8.jar"/>
> > <pathelement location="${dir.build}"/>
> > <pathelement path=""/>
> > <pathelement path="${java.class.path}"/>
> > </classpath>
> > </java>
> > </target>
> > my ultimate goal for the build process is to compile the source,
test
> > the compiled source code with
> > junit, and throw build exceptions any time an error or failure is
made
> > during the testing. if all of the
> > tests pass then the build would continue on to a publish task
that would
> > post the code to the net.
>
> The <junit> and <batchtest> tasks can do what you want. Is there a
> reason you don't want to use <junit>? Presumably in the future, it
could
> have more and better features. Not only that, why not reuse someone
> else's good work?
>
> I would use <junit> until I needed it to do something it didn't do.
